content.body:
> <@pchimento:igalia.com> `Function.call.bind(Function.call)` has more `.` than `f=>f()`, so I don't get it

We've also noticed significant performance improvements with the latter for our `uncurryThis` when going from `fn => (thisArg, ...args) => apply(fn, thisArg, args);` to `bind.bind(bind.call);`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @pchimento:igalia.com
Function.call.bind(Function.call) has more . than f=>f(), so I don't get it
We've also noticed significant performance improvements with the latter for our uncurryThis when going from fn => (thisArg, ...args) => apply(fn, thisArg, args); to bind.bind(bind.call);

content.body: I mean it doesn't surprise me with that level of indirection and temporary object creation
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I mean it doesn't surprise me with that level of indirection and temporary object creation

content.body: bound functions have special representation that's cheaper, and also special calling stubs i think
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: bound functions have special representation that's cheaper, and also special calling stubs i think

content.body: nodejs's movement to primordials drove a lot of improvements in v8 there
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: nodejs's movement to primordials drove a lot of improvements in v8 there

content.body: cuz it uses lots of super ugly .bind hacks
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: cuz it uses lots of super ugly .bind hacks

content.body: I think web uses of .bind were also part of what drove improvements
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think web uses of .bind were also part of what drove improvements

content.body: there was a weird period of time when microbenchmarks showed you should switch from .bind to arrow functions, and then I guess the two constructs were racing for a time
